contextId.information: Here "their hearts" is a metonym for the people's thoughts. AT: "were thinking to themselves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: reasoned in their hearts

contextId.information: Here the word "hear" means to pay attention. AT: "must pay careful attention to what I am saying" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: let him hear

contextId.information: The "word" represents God's message. Sowing the message represents teaching it. AT: "the one who teaches people God's message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the one who sows the word

contextId.information: Here "the sickle" is a metonym that stands for the farmer or the people who the farmer sends out to harvest the grain. AT: "he immediately goes out with a sickle to harvest the grain" or "he immediately sends out people with sickles to harvest the grain" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: he immediately sends out the sickle

contextId.information: Here Herod uses the word "I" to refer to himself. The word "I" is a metonym for Herod's soldiers. AT: "whom I commanded my soldiers to behead" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: whom I beheaded

contextId.information: Herodias is the subject of this phrase and "she" is a metonym as she wants someone else to execute John. AT: "she wanted someone to kill him, but she could not have him killed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: wanted to kill him, but she could not

contextId.information: Here "heart" refers to a person's thoughts or emotions. This is a way of saying the people are not truly devoted to God. AT: "but they do not really love me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: but their heart is far from me

contextId.information: Here "heaven" refers to the place where God lives, and it is a metonym for God. AT: "from God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: from heaven

contextId.information: "carry his cross and follow me." The cross represents suffering and death. Taking up the cross represents being willing to suffer and die. AT: "must obey me even to the point of suffering and dying" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and  [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: take up his cross, and follow me

contextId.information: The kingdom of God coming represents God showing himself as king. AT: "God show himself with great power as king" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the kingdom of God come with power

contextId.information: The "voice" is a metonym for God. Also, the "voice" is described as "coming out of the cloud," meaning that they heard God speaking from the cloud. AT: "Then God spoke from the cloud" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: Then a voice came out of the cloud

contextId.information: Here "hand" is a metonym for desiring to do something sinful that you would do with your hand. AT: "If you want to do something sinful with one of your hands" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: If your hand causes you to stumble

contextId.information: Here the word "foot" is a metonym for desiring to do something sinful that you would do with your feet, such as going to a place you should not go to. AT: "If you want to do something sinful with one of your feet" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: If your foot causes you to stumble

contextId.information: Here the word "eye" is a metonym for either 1) desiring to sin by looking at something. AT: "If you want to do something sinful by looking at something, tear your eye out."  Or 2) Desiring to sin because of what you have looked at. AT: "If you want to do something sinful because of what you look at, tear your eye out" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: If your eye causes you to stumble, tear it out

contextId.information: "when you are glorified." The phrase "your glory" refers to when Jesus is glorified and rules over his kingdom. AT: "when you rule in your kingdom" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: in your glory

contextId.information: Here David's ancestral line is referred to as himself. AT: "of the line of our father David" or "descended from our father David" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: of our father David

contextId.information: Here "heaven" refers to God. AT: "from God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: from heaven

contextId.information: Jesus is teaching that his people must respect the government by paying taxes. This figure of speech can be clarified by changing Caesar to Roman government. AT: "Give to the Roman government the things that belong to the Roman government" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Give to Caesar the things that are Caesar's

contextId.information: Jesus uses the metonym "my name" to refer to himself. AT: "because of me" or "because you believe in me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: because of my name

contextId.information: The word "he" refers to God and is a metonym for his angels, as they are the ones who will gather the elect. AT: "they will gather" or "his angels will gather" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: he will gather

contextId.information: Here the "Passover" refers to the Passover meal. AT: "eat the Passover meal" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: eat the Passover

contextId.information: Jesus speaks of the suffering that he must endure as if it were a cup. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Remove this cup from me

contextId.information: These refer to two different aspects of Peter. "The spirit" is his inmost desires. "The flesh" is his human ability and strength. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The spirit ... the flesh

contextId.information: They were not the ones who would execute Jesus; rather, they would order someone else to do it. AT: "they might have Jesus executed" or "they might have someone execute Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: they might put him to death

contextId.information: They commanded for Jesus to be bound, but it would have been the guards who actually bound him and led him away. AT: "they commanded for Jesus to be bound and then he was led away" or "they commanded the guards to bind Jesus and then they led him away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: they bound Jesus and led him away

contextId.information: Joseph had help from other people to take Jesus down from the cross, preparing it for the tomb, and closing the tomb. AT: "He and others took him down ... Then they rolled a stone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: He took him down ... Then he rolled a stone

contextId.information: This is a metonym for eating, which was the usual way people in that day ate meals. AT: "they were eating a meal" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: they were reclining at the table

contextId.information: This is a hyperbole, an exaggeration, and a metonym for the people in "all the world." AT: "absolutely everybody" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: the entire creation

contextId.information: Here "name" is associated with Jesus' authority and power. AT: "By the authority of my name" or "By the power of my name." See how "in your name" is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:mrk:09:38|9:38]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: In my name
